questions.question: Initial professional education is a characteristic of a profession.
Accreditation is not related to professional ethics.
Skills development is a characteristic of a profession.
Certification is not a part of professional ethics.
Licensing is a characteristic of a profession.
Professional development is not related to professional ethics.
Code of ethics is a characteristic of a profession.
Professional society is not related to professional ethics.
Software engineering is considered a profession.
Whistleblowing is not discussed in the context of professional ethics.
Professionals are expected to act for the public good.
A CPA requires only a high school diploma to become certified.
To become a CPA, one needs to complete 150+ semester hours of education.
CPAs must pass an exam to retain their certification.
Software Engineers are not considered professionals.
A software engineer must analyze user requirements.
Writing and testing code is not part of a software engineer's responsibilities.
Software engineers do not need to communicate with other programmers involved in the project.
Researching, designing, and writing new software programs is a task for software engineers.
Software engineers work closely with project managers and graphic artists.
Software engineers do not interact with sales and marketing teams.
Making incompatible platforms work together is a responsibility of a software engineer.
Creating technical specifications is part of software engineering tasks.
Operational documentation is written without the involvement of technical authors.
Maintaining systems involves monitoring but not correcting software defects.
The Software Engineering Code includes eight principles.
The eight principles identify key ethical relationships and obligations.
Public service is not one of the eight principles in the Software Engineering Code.
Client and employer considerations are part of the eight principles.
Product quality is not mentioned in the Software Engineering Code principles.
Judgment is one of the eight principles in the Software Engineering Code.
Management requirements are excluded from the Software Engineering Code principles.
The Code reflects principles drawn from multiple ethical theories.
If the Code doesn’t forbid something, it means it is morally acceptable.
Virtue Ethics originated from Aristotle.
There is a mechanical process for determining if an action is right or wrong.
Happiness results from living a life of virtue.
Intellectual virtue is developed through education.
Moral virtue is developed by repeating inappropriate acts.
Deriving pleasure from a virtuous act is a sign that the virtue has been acquired.
Benevolence, courage, fairness, generosity, honesty, loyalty, patience, and tolerance are some virtues.
A person of strong moral character knows the right thing to do in each situation.
Virtue ethics provides a solution to the problem of impartiality.
All virtues must be impartial.
Generosity is an example of a partial virtue.
Honesty is an example of a partial virtue.
Virtue ethics provides a clear methodology for answering moral problems.
Be impartial is one of the fundamental principles of professional ethics.
Disclosing information that others ought to know is not part of professional ethics.
Respecting the rights of others is a principle of professional ethics.
Treating others justly is not mentioned in the fundamental principles of professional ethics.
Taking responsibility for your actions and inactions is part of professional ethics.
You do not need to take responsibility for the actions of those you supervise.
Continually improving your abilities is a principle of professional ethics.
Sharing knowledge is not included in the fundamental principles of professional ethics.
Prof. Smith freely gave valuable information.
Prof. Smith did not reveal conflict of interest.
A whistleblower tries to report harmful situations through unauthorized channels.
A whistleblower is always supported by the organization.
Whistleblowers are punished for their actions by losing their job or all chances of advancement.
The false Claims Act is designed to protect whistleblowers.
The Whistleblower Protection Act is intended to safeguard individuals who report misconduct.
The Challenger explosion in 1986 involved documented warnings from engineers about the dangers of low temperatures.
Financial and emotional hardship are not common consequences for whistleblowers.
Morton Thiokol executives and NASA officials hid their concerns.
Roger shared information with the Presidential Commission.
People become whistleblowers for the same reasons.
The morality of action may depend on the motives of the whistleblower.
Desire to help the public is a questionable motive for whistleblowing.
Retaliation is considered a good motive for whistleblowing.
Avoiding punishment is a valid reason for whistleblowing.
Whistleblowers are often viewed as disloyal by corporations.
The public can use legal remedies to seek damages if a company causes harm.
Whistleblowing is seen as a sign of organizational success.
Whistleblowing can lead to ruined careers.
Publicity can lead to negative media attention.
Disruption of an organization’s social fabric makes it easier for people to work as a team.
Whistleblowing harms the whistleblower.
Retaliation is a positive outcome of whistleblowing.
Estrangement refers to being accepted within a group.
Organizations should improve communication.
Robert Spitzer suggests organizations should use principle-based ethics in decision making.
Price fixing is an example of unethical decision-making.
Over-billing or billing for services not performed is considered ethical behavior.
Concealing safety concerns is a moral duty.
false certifications by educational institutions are ethical practices.
Whistleblowing is considered a moral duty by Richard DeGeorge.
Richard DeGeorge suggests that serious harm to the public is not a factor in whistleblowing.
Telling your manager about an issue is one of Richard DeGeorge’s questions for whistleblowing.
Still others: Whistleblowing is never morally required
